discourse_list.title: Who do I call, if I want to call MakerDao?

content.content: Today was great in term of price and volume  , but while the exchange rate is soaring and the MKR is hitting ATH prices, an old unresolved question has been raised in my mind, from years ago. The famous question,  attributed to Henry Kissinger,  "WHO DO I CALL, IF I WANT TO CALL EUROPE? " raises a problem I don’t see clear about MakerDao - and DAOs in general. Europe is still very much seen as a continent of cooperating countries, not as a single EU bloc of 27 member states, where everyone has their own point of view.  This line-up looks very similar to me a organization like MakerDAO where the Core Units responsible for operations are in a juxtaposed relationship with each other, and governance is by vote of a very broad, worldwide shareholder base (although not so broad at the moment, but not relevant here), it raises general questions for me. This kind of governance with the active involvement of the foundation was perfectly adequate in ‘peacetime’, but now things have accelerated, which is both good and worrying for me. A bit I see MakerDAO growing more and more, and nowadays start to looks like a tanker: big and heavy, therefore slow and difficult to turn (and of course, very valuable  ) and the channel of good decisions on which we sail, is very narrow .   I think the difficulty in quick responding is caused by differences in language, education, social, legal, technical and other skills of the MKR owners who add their votes to operate the system. What other difficulties -and solutions- do you see in this area?   The more valuable the system becomes, the more people will try to attack it and immediate response will be vital. OK, suppose we can shut down the system if there’s a serious attack. But what if, every week, there are serious attacks on the system just because it’s so valuable that it’s worth it.  We cannot shut down the system every week… or can we?   I have more questions, but I don’t want to write much. If a discussion on this topic unfolds here, I’ll post it later.

content.content: So I think this is a really good question. And I don’t have an answer. But I’d like to piggyback a related question about who – operationally – is tying together the different units. For example, today I was on a call with several folks at a bank. First, let’s just appreciate that the MakerDAO name is so respected that I – some guy without even a MakerDAO email address – can get three decision-makers at a crypto-oriented bank to sit down on a call with just an email. We need to protect that kind of brand name and importance in the crypto ecosystem. Secondly, we were brainstorming collaborations and they ranged very widely. Aside from the obvious talk about vaults (hello, Growth CU!), there was also some pontificating and discussion about our oracle network (hello, Oracle CU!), and a very lengthy discussion about how to integrate our governance activities into their platform to increase participation (hello, Governance CU!) since MKR holders can already vote on-chain through this bank’s custodial platform. I’ve had a few other calls this week that were originally about pushing vaults or accepting DAI that meandered across these different DAO mandates. I think it will be difficult for our hardworking staff in various CU’s to avoid missing what could be great opportunities that come up by happenstance. I don’t know how to square that circle. But it made me really appreciate that there are a lot of different ways that institutions and businesses are open to being involved with the DAO, but the question I got in every meeting was “Who do I talk to if I want to proceed with X a month from now?”

content.content: My two cents is that the contact persons depending on the need should be the particular CU and the related facilitators. For press inquiries, I believe David U put something together, but generally funneling interested individuals into the forums with a list of optimal contacts (say, if you want Oracles, talk to X; if you want Smart Contract consulting, talk to Y) could be the way to go. The important point is to ensure that people look to the DAO and not the Foundation (which is dissolving) for communications and touchpoints. Thankfully, the Foundation seems to have embraced dissolution and becomes quieter by the day, which should cut any final “dependencies” from our (the DAO’s) perspective. Tosh

PaperImperium:  but the question I got in every meeting was “Who do I talk to if I want to proceed with X a month from now?”   Actually the answer to that is not necessarily too different from working with any complex large organisation (even centralised ones). Should someone ask you from outside say a tradFi bank:  “who do I talk to if I need to borrow XX amount for my business?” “who should I talk to if I have a plan to securitise XX amount of debt?” “who should I talk to if I plan to pitch an idea to the bank’s venture lab?” …  It could go on and on. For all of those questions, it would be a completely different answer. If you wanted business lending, it would point you to business lending, for securitisation the structured finance team and so. In that sense, MakerDAO is not really different. The core difference is that  for once all sc are opensource so you see what’s going on and you need to understand your use case better: are we talking RWAs, are we talking crypto-native, are we talking oracle services etc.  The other core difference is the required coordination between teams, say RWAs required a bunch of coordination between the RWA team, oracles, smart contracts and external parties (Centrifuge or LendCo). But that is on the implementation side. So you would still have similar coordination hurdles to overcome in a tradFi bank, it’s just that as a customer you don’t see it happening, whereas at Maker stuff is open so discussions/coordination happen in open/public forums.

content.content: Yes, it’s unpleasant not to be able to answer basic questions, which is why I avoid to start such conversations. But I was basically thinking of a Black Thursday-type event here. The system has become bigger and more complex since then and I don’t see who can provide an immediate emergency response to such an event. As we saw with Black Thursday, a rapid response is vital in such an event - or at least can prevent a lot of damage. Black Thursday will not happen again in the same form, but as the system becomes more complex, there will be more and more potential for security flaws.
